revised_title: Revised Theory of Metallurgical Phase Transformations in Rubbing of Steels
tldr: The authors re-examine the theory of frictionally generated temperatures that create hard, metallurgically transformed layers in the rubbing of steels. They find that these temperatures are much higher than previously assumed, with carbon diffusion being the rate-determining process. The revised theory is confirmed through experiments that produce phase-transformed material as a result of a single rubbing contact.
